# Python

Lately we've been learning new features via python and they have been been remarkably useful in many aspects including biology. When working in labs, there are times when we need to analyze DNA sequences but it can get quite tedious to do it by hand. A good example of the application of python in biological analytics was in HW 11 from my SDS348 class. It utilized a sequence of characters known as string that in this case contained DNA nucleotide bases and asked about its fragmentation. The function re.findall() was used to find all the matches and return them as a list of strings, with each string representing one match. 

# DNA Question
Note that per the IUPAC nucleotide code, N is any base, R is A or G, W is A or T. 
How many cuts total in the sequence do you expect if you digest with both of these restriction enzymes? How many fragments do you expect?

```{r}
string5=""
```

Solution by using re.findall() to match restriction enzyme binding sites ANTAAT and GCRWTG
```{r}
# re.findall(r'(A.TAAT)|(GC[AG][AT]TG)', string5)
# I was expecting to make 4 cuts and 5 fragments
```

```{r}
# [('', 'GCGTTG'), ('ATTAAT', ''), ('', 'GCAATG'), ('ACTAAT', '')]
```
